subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Petrol Prices

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. I refer the minister to an answer given in question time in the House of Representatives yesterday by Minister Vaile where he stated in regard to fuel prices:

question.para: In my electorate alone, I am aware that the retail price of petrol has fallen from some 79c to 72c. Apply the equation under our tax reform package to that, and it will fall even further.

I ask the minister: in light of evidence from the Australian Automobile Association that the rural-city fuel price differential will actually increase as a result of the GST, can the minister advise as to what equation Minister Vaile was referring to when he made his statement yesterday. Further, in regard to Minister Vaile's claim that fuel will fall even further, what does the cut in excise per litre of fuel have to be to ensure that rural fuel prices in fact fall, as is claimed by Minister Vaile?

talk.start.para: —Thank you for that question. Senator, we, as you are aware, are cutting fuel excises. We are doing it so business can benefit very substantially. It is one of the very big pluses I would put to you, Senator, of the tax package that we have brought before this parliament. This is quite in contrast with the rise in fuel prices which occurred under the Labor Party in 1993. In 1993—and I am sure my Labor colleagues will correct me if I am wrong—fuel prices rose in the order of 5c to 7c per litre.
—What did Murphy say?

—Senator Conroy, that is what happened under your government. You lifted fuel prices. Senator, if you go back to 1983, I think you will find there was a huge rise in fuel excise prices under the Labor Party.
—Murphy said the gap is getting wider.
—And let me say it was without any compensation being offered to rural Australia or anything else. Senator, what we have said—and I am reading from a press release that the Treasurer has put out—

answer.para: Senator Conroy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Conroy! Senator Kemp, I suggest you ignore Senator Conroy.

—Thank you, Madam President. Senator, you should be aware that for any business user entitled to a full credit on input tax the cost falls by some 10c, as business users are entitled to the full credit of the GST. In addition, Senator, heavy transport vehicles are entitled to an additional credit on fuel excise. Diesel excise for on-road use will fall to 18c per litre from the current level in the order of some 43c per litre. This will dramatically cut transport costs, particularly transport costs in rural and regional Australia.

answer.para: Senator Conroy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I was asked about transport costs and petrol costs and I have supplied the answer to you, Senator. But I do make the point that we in this government have a package designed to help rural and regional Australia, and that is why we have given those special concessions on diesel fuel. The Labor Party, when it was in government, raised the price of fuel to regional and rural Australia and to cities. Yet a Labor Party senator has got up and complained to us. The other point I would make is that we are attempting to deliver to the Australian people $13 billion worth of tax cuts, arguably the largest tax cuts in Australian history.

answer.para: Senator Conroy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —That is what we are trying to deliver, and the Labor Party is attempting to prevent us from delivering those tax cuts.
—Senator Conroy, you persistently interjected during that answer.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you, Minister, for that long-winded diatribe but you actually did ignore the two aspects of the question that I put to you—that is, Senator Vaile's statement as to the equation and, secondly, what the actual cut would be. Minister, I further ask you: will you guarantee that rural fuel prices will in fact fall as a result of the GST, as is claimed by Minister Vaile? Do you also agree with the Australian Automobile Association statement that a cut of 8.9c per litre is required just to ensure that country fuel prices will not rise? If you do not agree, what rate of excise cut do you believe is required to ensure that rural fuel prices will not rise—or, Minister, don't you really understand the question?
—I am not aware that there is anyone called Senator Vaile in this chamber.
—I meant Minister Vaile.

—Thank you, Senator, that is a different matter. I do not think you actually appreciate the nature of the question you are asking. You seem to have missed the key point. What I said was that heavy transport vehicles are entitled, as you should be aware, to an additional fuel credit on excise. Diesel excise for on-road use will fall, and fall substantially.
—We are talking about the motorist in the country. We are talking about the price of fuel to the country motorist.

—I have explained this to you very carefully, Senator, and you keep on shouting out. You do not understand. In our tax package we are cutting diesel fuel excise. Don't you understand that, Senator? Don't you understand that very important part of our tax package? We believe that this package is extremely good for rural and regional Australia. It is extremely good and I suggest—(Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator Vanstone. Minister, are you aware of statistics released recently by the Australian Institute of Criminology and the Productivity Commission that confirm something that has been clear for some time: that is, that New South Wales has a crime problem which is far more serious than any other state, in particular Victoria? Is there any truth in the claims made by Bob Carr that the New South Wales crime wave is due to drugs?

—I thank Senator Tierney for his very appropriate question. The figures in New South Wales on crime are very clear. As the Director of the Australian Institute of Criminology, Dr Adam Graycar, so eloquently stated yesterday in a keynote speech to the Third National Outlook Symposium on Crime in Australia:

answer.para: There is no doubt that in virtually every area the statistics show that rates of crime in New South Wales are higher than in other states.
Indeed, Dr Graycar asked this question during his keynote address to the conference:
Why has assault increased by 44 per cent in New South Wales but by only 1.5 and 2.8 per cent in South Australia and Victoria?
He went on:

Why does the rate per 100,000 of armed robbery range from 9.5 in Tasmania to 79.3 in New South Wales? Or, why does New South Wales have a rate that is three times that of Victoria? Why, over the past five years, has the rate of armed robbery in New South Wales gone up by a 105 per cent, that in Victoria by 15 and stayed constant in Tasmania?
Turning to unarmed robbery, Dr Graycar continued:

The range goes from 22 per 100,000 in Tasmania to 121 in New South Wales, with the rate in New South Wales 4.3 times that of Victoria. Over the past five years Victoria's rate grew by 35 per cent while that in New South Wales grew by 97 per cent.

Why indeed has the New South Wales crime rate soared in the past four years under Labor? Bob Carr's excuse is to blame drugs for his state's crime wave. And it is true that New South Wales has a serious and growing drug problem which is largely responsible for its crime problem. No one doubts that there is a link between drugs and crime, Madam President. The AIC conference heard from Dr Toni Makkai that the continued use of illicit drugs by petty criminals frequently leads them into more serious crime.

The burning question is: what is the New South Wales government doing about it? Last week when the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence report on illicit drugs was re leased, we could see at last what the real facts are. The New South Wales government is way behind the Victorian government in targeting drug dealers. In 1997-98 the Victorian police managed to arrest 1,901 heroin drug dealers—nearly 2,000 drug dealers in Victoria arrested in the relevant financial year—while in New South Wales only 685 dealers were arrested. Those figures speak for themselves. New South Wales has a higher population and when you take that into account Victoria is arresting three times as many—nearly a 3 to 1 difference. When you also remember that New South Wales accounts for 62 per cent of all customs seizures of heroin by weight, you can see why you would expect the arrest of dealers to be higher in New South Wales, not one-third of what it is in Victoria. New South Wales is clearly the state that heroin traffickers want to supply in. New South Wales is the state that has, unfortunately, the largest heroin demand.

This is just one indication—and there are more—of where New South Wales is not doing what it should be doing to restore law and order to New South Wales. They are not doing the job. They can have all the TV ads they like but the figures speak for themselves. New South Wales has a population higher than Victoria but arrests only one-third the heroin dealers that Victoria does. That might be the answer to why they have the problem. If Bob Carr was serious about it—

talk.start.para: —Senator, you should refer to him as the Premier, Mr Carr.

—Oh, sorry Madam President. I do apologise. If Premier Carr really believed drugs were the reason for the crime wave, he would in fact be targeting dealers—not doing only one-third of what Victoria does. (Time expired)

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, could you outline to the Senate what measures you feel the New South Wales government should be taking to improve its appalling record on drug prevention and remediation, particularly in light of the experiences of states like Victoria?

question.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators on my left will cease shouting. To the extent to which it is within your portfolio, Minister, you may respond.

—Thank you Madam President. What I was pointing out was that, if Premier Carr did believe that drugs were responsible for the crime wave, he would ensure that the policing effort was directed at pushers rather than users. The ABCI statistics make clear that the New South Wales users are targeted more than dealers by comparison with Victoria and that makes no sense. It means you give your priority to punishing the victims rather than the real criminals. A policy of being tough on drugs means targeting the pushers where you can rather than the addicts.

answer.para: I might add that New South Wales cannot even arrest and prosecute the perpetrators of a whole range of other crimes. We know that they proceed against offenders of armed robbery in only 16 per cent of cases—less than half the rate for Victoria. They proceed in unarmed robbery cases against only 10 per cent of offenders—again, less than half the rate for Victoria. The figures speak for themselves, Madam President. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Local Government

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Will the minister admit that, in response to a question in the Senate yesterday about local government, he selectively and misleadingly quoted from a radio interview with the CEO of the Australian Local Government Association, Mr Rod Nettle? Can the minister confirm that Mr Nettle—

question.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators on my left should remain silent while one of their own senators is asking a question, so that it can be heard.
—Can the minister confirm that Mr Nettle, in the same interview, went on to say—and I quote:

question.para: The Australian Local Government Association is going to some trouble to say "look this is actually how the GST works and this is what you need to have a think about before you put the legislation through", and the legislation at the moment, of course, is that dodgy it's quite amazing; they're going to have to fix it up quite substantially.
Why did the minister mislead the Senate yesterday?

talk.start.para: —I call Senator Kemp.
—Madam President, the question was to Senator Macdonald.
—Order! I am not surprised, there is so much noise in the chamber. The question was to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp.

—Madam President, I am very happy to answer the question. I say to Senator Mackay: thank you for the question to me. It gives me a chance to read some more of the comments made by Mr Rod Nettle. I have a brief here; I thank my colleague the very effective and popular Senator Ian Macdonald for the brief. The first quote I read was—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I was asked whether I selectively quoted. I am now quoting exactly what Mr Rod Nettle said. According to my brief, it says:

answer.para: Senate committees themselves, really are a bit of window-dressing for the government's policy. They are determined to get the GST through, and I think that's fair enough. They can claim a reasonable mandate for it.
That is the first quote from Mr Rod Nettle. The second quote was:

The committees are not doing anything in detail and I rather get the impression it's sort of split down the middle. The Labor and Democrats side is just opposed to it, or the Labor side at least is opposed to it and the Democrats aren't quite sure what they're doing with it at all.
That was the second quote from Mr Rod Nettle. Thank you for the question, Senator, by the way. I think you have been very selective with your quotes. The next quote from Mr Rod Nettle was:
They are pretty lightweight sort of affairs, these inquiries.
The other quote was:
At the moment, everything is taxed by the GST, or it will be, anyway.
That shows, to my mind, Nettle's lack of comprehension about the policy. Senator, we have quoted Mr Nettle, and I have shown you some of the upsides of Mr Nettle's quotes.

talk.start.para: —Why did you mislead the Senate?
—Order, Senator Faulkner!

—I did not mislead the Senate at all. In fact, Senator Mackay said that I had selectively quoted. Of course, seeing that you have about four minutes in which to answer a question, you will generally be a little selective in your quotes.
—A little bit selective?
—But you have been selective in your quotes. When he referred to the committee hearings he referred to them as `pretty lightweight sorts of affairs, these inquiries'.
—Senator, you should address your remarks to the chair.
—That is what Mr Rod Nettle said about your inquiry, Senator Mackay. You did not quote that. I am quoting that back to you.
—Senator Kemp!
—Thank you, Madam President. There may be a frank exchange of selective quotes here. If I have been selective in my quotes, Madam President, I can assure you so has Senator Mackay.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I wish to remind the minister of Mr Nettle's quote:

question.para: . . . the legislation at the moment, of course, is that dodgy it's quite amazing; they're going to have to fix it up quite substantially.
At the beginning of that interview, there was also a quote from Councillor John Campbell. Is the minister aware of this quote:
It was pretty clear that the Government members on that Committee essentially didn't know much about the GST and community services and how it was all going to pan out.
Is the minister now aware that not one local government organisation or council publicly supported the tax package as it currently stands?

talk.start.para: —Madam President—

question.para: Senator Faulkner interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Faulkner, you do not have the call.

—In response to Senator Mackay's question, I notice that she did not say that I had not quoted what Mr Nettle said in an accurate fashion. All that Senator Mackay was worried about was that I looked at particular quotes made by Mr Nettle to give a better perspective than that given by the sorts of quotes referred to by Senator Mackay. I will share one final quote by Mr Rod Nettle which I think goes to the heart of the debate that we are having. The quote was: `They'—the government—`can claim a reasonable mandate for it.' That is what Mr Rod Nettle said, and it is what you did not say when you gave your quotes. Senator Mackay, thank you very much for the question.

—My question is to the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, Senator Ian Macdonald. The Howard-Fischer government has an excellent record in improving services to regional and rural Australia, moving to restore many services that were allowed to deteriorate under the rabble on the other side when they were in government.
—Senator Brownhill, phrase your question without that language, please.
—Can the minister outline what the government is doing to put basic services back into small communities, particularly in light of the recent report into regional banking services.

question.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators on my left are in breach of the standing orders and have been persistently during this question time.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Brownhill who, like me, comes from the country. Unfortunately none of the Labor senators do, so they do not understand what it is like providing services and they do not understand the impact that their government had on rural and regional Australia in the 13 years they were in office. That is the time when the banks left the bush. That is the time when the services left rural and regional Australia. I do appreciate Senator Brownhill raising this important matter.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senators on my left will cease shouting.

—At least, Madam President, Senator Brownhill knows who to ask his questions of. Unfortunately, Senator Mackay directs local government questions not to the local government minister but to another minister. I can only suggest that she is no longer game to ask me a question because she has been wrong so often on local government—
—Senator Macdonald, I invite you to apply yourself to the question you have been asked.
—Order! There are far too many interjections on both sides of the chamber.

—Senator Brownhill does raise a very important and timely question in view of the release of the report by Mr David Hawker's Joint Standing Committee on Economics, Finance and Public Administration into regional banking services. That committee inquiry was set up about 17 months ago to look specifically into alternative means of providing banking and like services to rural and remote Australia—services that as I say, and emphasise, left the bush under the term of the Labor government, and they did absolutely nothing about it.

answer.para: As a result of this inquiry and the government focusing on this inquiry and of the work that we have done, a number of banks and banking institutions are already moving back into the bush. That is good news. Members and senators would have heard about the Pharmacy Guild-Bank West proposal announced just a couple of days ago. That is an initiative which we support, done entirely by private enterprises. I am also very pleased to know of the Bendigo Bank initiative, which is returning very good services to the bush.

Some of the committee's recommendations are interesting. A recommendation was that the federal government should undertake to assist communities to utilise the Regional Telecommunications Infrastructure Fund to expand the number of Internet service points. It also recommended that we should ensure that the rural transaction centres build upon state government initiatives. It recommended as well that the federal government give high priority to determining the scope of rural transaction centres.

talk.start.para: —We can read it ourselves.

—I hear Senator Mackay saying that she can read it herself. It is a pity she has not done so. Perhaps she could ask me a question about it. I know that her shadow minister, Ms Kernot, is not interested in the bush. We have used the Regional Telecommunications Infrastructure Fund. We funded over 140 projects, which involved the expansion of access to the Internet at local call rates. We are providing Internet access to indigenous communities and to rural youth. We are installing mobile phone systems in remote communities. We are funding telemedicine projects and assisting projects specifically designed to ease the life of rural women.

answer.para: As part of the social bonus from the sale of the next 16 per cent of Telstra, the federal government has committed $36 million to ensuring Internet access at local call rates for all Australians. And so it goes on. A week or so ago Mr Anderson and I were proud to launch the Howard government's Rural Transaction Centres Program. That program will provide $70 million over five years, to be funded from the sale of the next 16 per cent of Telstra, to establish some 500 rural transaction centres. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister give further details about the timetable for the rural transaction centres and the government's commitment to providing vital services to smaller communities?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I can give Senator Brownhill some information. The guidelines were launched on 11 March. I have written to all local government councils, post office agencies, senators and members, every state and territory regional development minister, progress associations and community associations—around 3,000 letters in all—telling them of the RTC program and giving them information. My department has set up a secretariat. Application forms are available. They will be either posted out or downloaded from the web site.

answer.para: The Senate might be interested to know that the RTC hotline that we have set up has received over 237 inquiries since the program was announced. I am very pleased about the interest in rural and regional Australia in this program. We are very keen to progress the program. Whilst there is no particular closing date, applications will be dealt with as they come in and the advisory panel will recommend—(Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Compliance Burden

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Does the Assistant Treasurer agree with the Senate GST inquiry submission from Arthur Andersen which states:

question.para: A value added tax system is inherently complex and adds a substantial administrative and compliance burden to many businesses.
It continues:
Most GST taxpayers will be saddled with a substantial compliance burden but will contribute no net GST revenue.
Why does the government continue to claim that the GST is simple, when the experts confirm that the system is complex and involves a significant compliance burden?

talk.start.para: —Why do we claim that? Because all the facts point to it.
—Five times bigger than New Zealand.
—Senator Conroy!
—Thank you, Madam President. He calls out all the time. It is most distracting. The Labor government left us with a dreadful tax system—a tax system which was in fact breaking down.
—It is not broken.
—Senator Sherry says that it is not broken. Senator Sherry is the great supporter of the wholesale sales tax. Senator Sherry was the man that wanted all those added taxes on fuel excise.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are far too many interjections and far too much noise. I need to be able to hear what the senator with the call on either side is saying.

—In Australia, the single rate of GST will make the system simpler and reduce costs of collections. The GST that this government is proposing is simpler than most taxes overseas where differing rates, beloved of Senator Sherry and his mates, and numerous exemptions exist to create great complexity. For example, in Canada the sale of six donuts is GST free, while the sale of five donuts is taxable and is considered snack food. There is a whole host of examples that one could array to show why we are creating a simpler tax system in Australia.
—What about waffles, Rod?

—What about waffles! The Labor Party have really lost it, I would have to say. They have really lost it. The government estimates that the GST recurrent net compliance costs are $130 per registrant. This is based on a study of New Zealand's GST. Their GST is the closest one to that proposed for Australia. This is an average figure, of course, and small business is likely to have even smaller compliance costs.

answer.para: We believe that there are many features of tax reform which will reduce compliance costs for business. These include the removal of the wholesale sales tax, the abolition of state taxes—never mentioned by Senator Sherry—cash flow benefits to remitters and the amount that can be recouped by business through tax deductions. Further, as business becomes more familiar with the GST system, the government expects a significant reduction in compliance costs. The GST is only one part of tax reform.

talk.start.para: —What happened to Arthur Andersen in all this?

—We do not agree. I do not know whether that was the Arthur Andersen view. I think that was the view of a particular person from Arthur Andersen—one person. I think you should be careful when you claim that is the Arthur Andersen view because I think that you will find it was the view of one person from Arthur Andersen. We do not agree with that view.

answer.para: Can I make the point once again that this is a comprehensive tax reform package. Major features of the tax reform package are the massive tax cuts which are going to be provided—arguably the largest tax cuts in Australian history—and real rises in pensions and benefits. This is what the Labor Party is attempting to stop. This is what the Labor Party is attempting to defeat. Mr Beazley gets up one day and says that we should stop Senate obstruction, and up here his colleagues flout his particular views. The Labor Party are all over the place. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It is a direct quote from the official Arthur Andersen submission to the select committee. Minister, if a major international accounting firm such as Arthur Andersen does not believe this government's commitments on business costs of the GST, why should the people who really matter in this debate—the Australian people?

—I will have to read the Hansard carefully, but I took it that you qualified that. Did you say `one official' from Arthur Andersen or `an official' from Arthur Andersen? There is, let me say, quite a distinction, Senator. We do not agree with the view that was put by that official from Arthur Andersen to the committee. We believe that we are bringing about a very efficient tax system; a tax system which has very big benefits for the Australian economy, very big benefits for business, very big benefits for employees and for taxpayers and very big benefits for pensioners and those receiving other benefits. We are very proud of this tax package. We were that proud of it that we went to the people on it. What we say to the Senate is: make us keep our promises. That is what we say to you. Make us keep the promises on which we were elected.

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. I ask the minister: have all the documents requested in the Senate's return to order on Jabiluka been included in the list the minister tabled in the Senate and in the list of documents in his letter to me?

—I have tabled the documents that I have said I have tabled. I have to say that is what I thought the question was. I would like to congratulate Senator Allison for visiting Ranger last week, but I was particularly disappointed that she failed to take the opportunity to visit Jabiluka.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. I did not invite the minister to discuss my trip to Jabiluka or to Ranger. I did ask him a direct question, and that was whether all of the documents were included in the tabling statement and in his letter to me. It is a simple question, and I would be obliged if minister would answer it directly.
—The minister is only beginning his answer. I would remind him of the question.
—Alternatively, she did not visit Jabiluka because she could not find it. That would not surprise me because its impact is so small—only 22 hectares and outside the world heritage area.
—Madam President, my point of order is again on relevance. It is clear the minister is going to pursue this line and not answer the question. I ask you to direct him to answer the question.

—I cannot direct the minister as to how he answers the question; I can merely draw his attention to the question. He uses his discretion as to how he answers it, but must be within the degree of relevance.
—It could have been that she missed Jabiluka because she was searching for it within the world heritage area. In actual fact, the mine site is outside of the area.

answer.para: Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators on my right are behaving in a disorderly fashion.
—Madam President, my point of order again is one of relevance. The fact that Senator Allison has been to Jabiluka twice is of no relevance to this question. I ask the minister to answer the question.

—I cannot tell at this stage whether what the minister is saying is relevant or not. I need to hear more of it. He knows he must be relevant to the question that has been asked and needs to develop it in a way that makes what he is saying relevant.

—She should have been able to find the mine site, because Senator Bolkus was with her. So they both visited Ranger, had a look around but did not bother to go out to see Jabiluka. All this criticism of Jabiluka and writing off to the World Heritage Committee in Kyoto—

—Madam President, my point of order is not only on relevance but also the issue of debating the answer rather than giving an answer. It has already been pointed out that this is Senator Allison's third trip. She has been to Jabiluka twice previously. The minister is debating the issue and I would ask you to ask him to answer the question.
—Senator Hill, you should not be debating the answer, and I would draw your attention to the question.

—I am sorry, Madam President. I would have thought that she would have made an effort to visit the mine site, because she knows that it will generate $12 billion of revenue, 85 per cent of which will remain in Australia and will employ 380—
—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Senator Hill was asked whether all documents relating to Jabiluka were included in a list tabled in this parliament and sent to Senator Allison.
—Senators on my right! I need to hear what is being said.
—Certain freedom should be given to a minister to tee off on that—I have always conceded that—but Senator Hill has not addressed one aspect of the question.
—Three minutes to go.

—It does not matter whether there are one, two, three or four minutes to go. He should at least address that before he starts teeing off on everyone around the chamber. That is the tradition of this place. You cannot direct him how to answer the question, but he must be at least somewhat relevant.
—Senator Ray, the minister referred to the question of documents.
—The behaviour in the chamber is absolutely disgraceful for everybody who is watching and attempting to listen.
—You were right to sit Alston down.
—Senator Faulkner, when I am speaking I do not expect you to be shouting across the chamber.

—And I do not expect comment like that on my right, either. Senator Hill referred to documents when he first got to his feet, he referred to the documents that had been tabled and then went on to other aspects relating to Jabiru and Jabiluka. I assume he will be coming back to documents, but he certainly started his answer by referring to the matter of tabling of documents.

—Further to the point of order, Senator Hill referred to documents tabled in this chamber. He was not even asked about that. He was asked about the existence of all documents as related to two lists, not documents tabled in this chamber. So he has yet to be relevant one iota. In fact his very first reference to it was not in reference to the question asked of him.
—Senator Hill, I draw your attention to the question, if you have anything further to add.
—Senator Abetz!
—Be quiet, Eric, you're a fool.
—You are in no position to comment.

—As I said at the outset, I provided certain documents to the Senate. I provided a list of those documents and I provided a list of documents that I was unable to provide to the Senate, and I provided reasons for not so providing the documents. Beyond that, I am not sure to what the honourable senator is referring, but we do seem to have an exchange of correspondence in this matter. I am writing to her today in answer to her questions of yesterday. I will go back and reassess the lists that were provided and try to discover the point that she is seeking to make in question time today. If I can discover it and if I can help the honourable senator, I will do so.

—I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. I remind the minister that the question related to all documents requested by the Senate, not certain documents, and I ask: is it not the case that none of the documents from the minister's interdepartmental committee on Kakadu were tabled by the minister? They are certainly not in the letter to me, and they are certainly not in the tabling statement as being withheld. Will the minister table in the Senate, before close of business today, all of the documents, including those for and by the Kakadu interdepartmental committee?

—If she had asked that in the original question, I might have been able to discover what she was seeking. But my original answer to her said that there were only certain documents tabled. We did not seek to table all of the documents. I said that up front. I said it days and days ago, and I keep repeating it every question time. I also gave to the honourable senator details of the documents which were provided by my department to me but which I did not table. I will go back and look carefully at the question that has been asked today and see if there is any further information that I can provide.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Cost Reductions

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Does the Assistant Treasurer agree with Arthur Andersen's submission to the Senate GST inquiry which states:

question.para: There is no question that it will take years for the effects of the abolition of the wholesale sales tax and other tax changes to fully impact costs and prices.

The proposed removal of the advance instalment requirement really simpli fies the administrative arrangements for collection. It will lead to very significant cost savings in the future—I would submit it could be hundreds of thousands of dollars—that will flow not only to those who are subject to the surcharge but also to the millions of superannuation fund members who have to bear part of the cost of the administrative surcharge in terms of the calculation of the advance payment. It has indeed been a contentious and a difficult issue. For example, the advance payment is not paid in respect of defined benefit funds.

Honourable senators would be aware that contributions paid after 7.30 p.m. on 20 August 1996 are subject to the surcharge. The surcharge is payable on superannuation contributions where the member's adjusted taxable income for this financial year exceeds the surcharge threshold of $72,220 for 1997-98. The term `adjusted taxable income' is the ordinary taxable income of the taxpayer plus the amount of the surchargable superannuation contributions.

By way of background, the tax office calculates the rate and the amount of surcharge and makes an assessment directed to the holder of the contributions, and this can be one of a number of different people. The maximum rate of surcharge is 15 per cent and the surcharge is generally payable within one month of the assessment. As to the liability, where the surcharge is payable for a member for a financial year—the advance instalment that has now been removed—50 per cent is generally payable on account of the surcharge by 15 June in the following year. That is where some of the complications came in and that is why I applaud the removal of this advance payment. Both this step and the associated administrative difficulties will now be eliminated and will reduce the administrative cost for all members of the funds.

What are the advantages? The collection mechanism is of considerable administrative complexity and causes increased costs for all members of the fund. One of the most complicated elements of this—this add-on, this 50 per cent—will now be taken away, and I think this was a matter that was raised when it was first looked at by the superannuation committee. A number of members present in the Senate were members of that committee.

The proposal will simplify the administrative collection of the surcharge and, as I said, will lead to significant cost savings in the future. Some of the key advantages that will accrue include the following. It is more efficient because it removes a number of steps from this quite complicated collection process, and that has got to be good. It will save employers and superannuation funds significant amounts of time and money. It will also simplify the Australian Taxation Office workload. It will also reduce the number of staff members there to administer the surcharge. It will also eliminate the need for superannuation funds to hold reserves to cover the advance instalment, which was always a complicated issue. This will increase the fund liquidity, and obviously that is good for all members, particularly around 15 June when the second group instalment assessment and the advance instalment are due at the same time. In practice, many funds have needed to borrow to pay the advance instalment. That will no longer be necessary. The interest costs of borrowing will probably have been borne by all members. The whole purpose of introducing the surcharge was on account of equity. The removal of this advance payment improves the equity substantially of the surcharge regime. National savings will be also enhanced. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I table a statement by the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation entitled Safety of fire doors: notice of investigation and warning to the public . I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

Concerns about the safety of consumers in a large number of high occupancy buildings have led me to issue a notice of investigation and warning to the public under section 65B of the Trade Practices Act 1974 .

The Notice advises that a particular type of fire door, that is, fire doors using a Pyrokor core which were manufactured between 1993 and 3 September 1998, are under investigation to determine whether they will or may cause injury to any person. The notice was published in a special Commonwealth Government Gazette on Friday 19 March 1999.

Allegations that these fire doors do not meet mandatory building safety standards were first brought to my attention on 22 February 1999. I then asked the Department of the Treasury to obtain urgent technical advice from State/Territory building regulators and the Australian Building Codes Board on this issue and advise me accordingly.

Fire doors are required to satisfy the safety performance requirements of the Building Code of Australia 1996, which requires the doors to impede the passage of fire through a building. This means that fire doors must be manufactured and installed in accordance with Australian Standard 1905, Part 1.

In accordance with the Australian Standard, fire doors must be subjected to a standard fire test and be fire rated. For example, a fire door with a fire rating of one hour must impede the passage of fire through the door for at least one hour and a 2 hour fire rated door for at least two.
Fire doors therefore provide more time to enable the occupants of a building to evacuate in the event of a fire.

I have been provided with copies of fire door certification schedules which claim the Pyrokor fire doors meet the Building Code requirements. However, I have concerns about the validity of the certifications for two reasons.
Firstly, a number of the fire test reports being referenced actually show that the Pyrokor fire doors did not obtain the minimum fire rating of one hour.
Secondly, test reports on fire doors constructed of different materials were being referenced and reliance on these test reports would be invalid.
Thus the Pyrokor fire doors have been represented as complying with safety requirements, when they may not comply.

The ACCC is currently investigating the certificates of compliance for breaches of sections 52, 53(a) and 55 of the Trade Practices Act which deal with misleading and deceptive conduct and false representations.
This may have serious implications for those with responsibility for the inspection and approval of building works.

While enforcement of the Building Code of Australia is a State/Territory responsibility, the relevant Departments responsible for building regulation do not enforce the Building Code of Australia. This is done by local Councils, which have the power to approve building construction and declare buildings fit for occupancy or unsafe as the case may be.

If Councils were led to believe that the doors met required standards, they would naturally have approved the buildings. The Department has now written to State/Territory departments responsible for building regulation and asked that this matter be brought to the attention of local councils.

Under the Trade Practices Act 1974 , I have a range of powers to protect the public from unsafe goods. I can publish a notice stating that specified goods are under investigation and warning of the possible risk involved in their use.

I can also order the compulsory recall of goods if it appears to me that the goods "will or may cause injury" to any person and the supplier has not taken satisfactory action to prevent the goods causing injury to any person.
Fire doors that do not meet the relevant mandatory safety requirements of the Building Code of Australia may not provide the level of safety and protection expected by the community and Government.

I have also received expert technical advice from CSIRO that the installation of a Pyrokor door that does not meet the safety requirements represents a varying degree of life and property hazard. The hazard could be extreme in situations where the occupants are asleep or incapacitated, for example, hospitals and nursing homes.

In other occupancies, which contain various combinations of smoke detection and fire control systems, the risk to life would be considerably reduced, particularly if the buildings were only occupied for work purposes.

I have been advised that Pyrokor fire doors manufactured between 1993 and 3 September 1998 are installed in hospitals, nursing homes, schools, major shopping centres, stores and supermarkets, high rise home units, government buildings and private business premises.

Before considering the need to order a compulsory recall under the Trade Practices Act, I need to establish conclusively that the fire doors in question fail the Building Code safety requirements and that those failures actually pose a threat to the safety of occupants of buildings.

Minor technical breaches of the safety requirements may not provide sufficient evidence that the Pyrokor fire doors "will or may cause injury" and, as a consequence lead me to use my powers to order a compulsory recall under the Trade Practices Act.

I have asked the Department of the Treasury, therefore, to commission urgent testing of the fire doors by the CSIRO, to establish conclusively whether or not the fire doors installed in buildings meet safety requirements and to assess the safety implications, if the fire doors do not meet Building Code fire test requirements. These tests may provide conclusive evidence on which to base a compulsory recall under the Trade Practices Act 1974 .

Although there are varying degrees of risk, I am not prepared to take any chances when there is a potential risk to the lives of consumers and have therefore issued the notice of investigation and warning to the public under section 65B of the Trade Practices Act 1974 .
On completion of the investigation and testing of the Pyrokor fire doors, I will publish a further notice advising what action I intend to take.
