talk.start.para: —I am concerned about recent articles in the media reporting the increasing weight of Australians. Through the 1980s and the first half of the 1990s there has been an increase in the proportion of men and women who are overweight or obese. A recent article in Australia's Health 1998 quotes data from the risk factor prevalence surveys and the national nutrition survey. The proportion of overweight or obese women aged between 25 and 64 years has increased from 26.7 per cent in 1980 to 45.7 per cent in 1995, while the proportion of overweight men in the same age group has increased from 47.6 per cent to 66.3 per cent over the same period. The proportion of specifically obese men has increased dramatically from 7.8 per cent in 1980 to 17.6 per cent and, for women, from 6.9 per cent in 1980 to 16.1 per cent in 1995.

speech.para: In an article in the Australian Journal of Public Health, David Crawford and Neville Owen reveal that the prevalence of overweight and obesity varies according to socio-demographic characteristics. The odds of being overweight or obese are higher in persons born in Southern Europe compared with those born in Australia; for persons with a low level of education compared with those of tertiary education or qualifications; for married men compared with never-married men; for plant machinery operators compared with professional people; and for women in the two lowest socio-economic categories compared with those in the highest category.

Crawford and Owen believe the high prevalence of overweight and obesity, the biological consequence and the socio-demographic distribution make excess body weight a major public health problem. At all ages, significantly more men than women are overweight or obese. Studies show that women are more concerned with body weight than men and are more likely to take steps to reduce or to control it. This has led to some negative effects and unfortunate eating disorders. Men are concerned about being overweight but are less likely to do something about it.

The damage caused by obesity has led practitioners to urge governments to address weight gain as an urgent national health problem. Overweight and obesity increase the risk of diabetes, hypertension, heart disease, stroke, gout, sleep apnoea, gallstones, arthritis, some forms of cancer, impotence and infertility. One in three Australian families will be affected by heart disease or stroke. The latest figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics highlight the alarming fact that heart and blood vessel disease is a major public health problem facing Australia today, claiming one life every 10 minutes. The cost to the Australian national health system is absolutely enormous.

While there has been a marked improvement in blood pressure levels amongst men and women in Australia, data from the National Heart Foundation's risk factor prevalence study reveals that the average levels of blood cholesterol are too high and represent a national health problem. More than 47 per cent of men and 39 per cent of women aged between 20 and 69 years had plasma cholesterol levels above the National Heart Foundation's desirable level.

The 1980s and early 1990s were tough for Australians. We may be seeing the result of a society in a depressed mood—recession, unemployment and the decline of the family unit. It is recognised that the unemployed and those from low income groups have higher levels of overweight and obesity.

There is 24-hour television nowadays. We have computers, computer games and the Internet. These electronic devices, becoming more popular every day, keep people glued to their chairs. Let's face it: there is not much physical exercise in watching television or chatting on the Internet. Additionally, many people are employed in occupations that require little exercise. Take us, for example. We have a limited amount of time available for exercise. We can joke that we walk quite a number of kilometres each day around Parliament House, but how many of our staff take time out to exercise during the sitting weeks? There are people in the parliament who do exercise regularly and quite vigorously, such as Senator Alston. Senator Chapman is another. We all need to set aside time each day for daily exercise regularly and in moderation.

The National Heart Foundation reveals that treatment of established obesity is successful in a minority of cases, so particular attention needs to be devoted to the avoidance of obesity. Children consume a lot of food and they also watch a lot of television. Up to 93 per cent of television advertisements in children's timeslots are for food—and they are not for fruit and vegetables.

Too little time is spent on physical education in schools and too many fatty items are for sale in school canteens—no doubt the popular ones that are advertised on television—and, as mum and dad both work, the school lunch box is actually disappearing from the school grounds. The Australian Medical Association has called for rigorous exercise to be made compulsory in all schools to `help reverse the ballooning rate of fat Australians'. Perhaps school canteens should be encouraged to stock 100 per cent health food, not junk food. Workplace food should also be addressed and more emphasis paid to eating healthy food in the work environment. Unions and employer groups should be proactive in this area, recognising that physical activity and diet are part of occupational health and safety policies and practices. Local councils can also assist by constructing cycle and walking paths, skateboard parks and the like. There may be a case for government to actually introduce tax deductions for gym fees.

The National Health and Medical Research Council is extremely concerned about Australians getting fatter. Background papers contributed to the development of a single strategic plan for the prevention of overweight and obesity entitled `Acting on Australia's weight'. In summary, this report states that the trend of increasing levels of overweight and obesity in the population is likely to be the result of small decreases in physical activity and small changes in food intake by most rather than the extreme inactivity and excessive food intake among the few. Australians, therefore, eat too much and exercise too little. The National Health and Medical Research Council report states that many epidemiological studies report a negative correlation between physical activity and weight gain and that it is highly probable that the increase in overweight and obesity in Australia and similar societies over the past few decades is associated with a reduction in physical activity during the same period.

The strategic plan is about changing the macroenvironment to make it easier for people to undertake physical activity and to make healthier food choices. Its goals must be to prevent further weight gain in adults, to eventually reduce the proportion of the adult population that is overweight or obese and to ensure the healthy growth of children. The time frame for implementation of the strategy is 10 years, from January 1997, with an interim evaluation to take place after five years. I will eagerly await the progress reports.

The Life, be in it, `Norm', television advertisements, with their familiar music and quaint jingle, may be just what we need now to get us out of our armchairs and office chairs, away from the computer and television, onto our bikes and into our walking gear in order to exercise on a daily basis. I thank the Senate.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak tonight on a couple of issues. Firstly, briefly, I wish to remind the Senate of a motion passed by this chamber almost a year ago, on 25 March last year, which noted the commencement of the Victorian duck hunting season and which called on all state and territory governments to `ban the cruel and environmentally damaging practice of duck hunting'. Unfortunately, there has not been much progress in relation to banning that practice in those states where it is still continued, and last weekend we once again saw the Victorian duck hunting season commence. The Democrats believe that the institutionalised killing of native birds for recreation is an ugly practice that has no place anymore in Australian society and that it should not be tolerated. It has gone past its expiry date and needs to be thrown out, like the practice of whaling.

speech.para: I congratulate the many duck rescuers who tried to assist in saving native bird wildlife, including some protected species, last weekend. I congratulate not just veteran campaigners such as Laurie Levy but many other people doing it for the first time, including a number of Democrats and, indeed, the Victorian President of the Young Democrats, Amanda Leeper, who provided me with a report about some of the activities that happened there. There was a range of issues of great concern beyond just the slaughter of native birds, including illegal shooting at least half an hour before the official start, the killing of a number of protected species, swans and cygnets being shot, intimidation from balaclava wearing shooters throwing rescuers into the swamp and their cameras along with them, and various other practices. It is unfortunate that the police present at the scene, as has been the practice, tend to focus more on keeping protesters away from the duck shooters rather than on ensuring that the duck shooters do not inappropriately interfere with those people who are trying to rescue and save the lives of native wildlife.

The other issue I would like to speak in a little more depth on relates to piggeries. There has been a bit in the news of late about the piggery of the former Prime Minister, Mr Keating. Whilst debate rages about whether Paul Keating ripped off his piggery partner, misled the House of Representatives or did a deal with the Commonwealth Bank, there is one part of the issue that is being left out—that is, the pigs. In many ways, one might ask, `Why shouldn't they be left out? After all, they can't get an exclusive on 60 Minutes and they can't take part in shonky deals.' But they do pay the highest price of all—a miserable life, followed by a captive bolt in the head. That is why I think pigs and their welfare should not be forgotten.

Pigs farmed intensively are confined to life in sheds. Sows are kept in crates where they can take only one step forward and one back. They are never able to see the sun or a blade of grass, and the boredom and monotony of their existence drives many of them insane. Over five million pigs are killed each year in Australia for industry purposes and for food consumption. The vast majority of those are intensively farmed and suffer conditions such as those that prevailed at the piggery previously owned by the former Prime Minister at Parkville in New South Wales.

Rescue action by a number of activists in 1995 exposed that particular piggery for having horrendous animal cruelty practices. Over 30 animal rescuers entered that piggery on 20 November in that year, at the same time as the former Prime Minister was performing duties overseas in Japan. They entered the piggery to rescue sick pigs, to highlight the appalling conditions and to demand immediate action.

A lot of the accounts that I am about to mention to the Senate come from people who were present on that particular inspection of that piggery. Some of these insights were taken from those eyewitness accounts and the video footage taken at that time, which I have witnessed. The particular eyewitness account I am about to mention comes from well-known animal rights activist Lynda Stoner. It mentions that the overall aim of the inspection of the piggery was, firstly, to remove injured and ill piglets to a waiting vet, and then to obtain videotape and film evidence of the acts of cruelty that were continuing in the piggery and to highlight the unnatural existence of intensively farmed animals.

She spoke of the terrible stench of the shed. It was different to the stench of battery hen sheds, no ammonia burning into the lungs, but terrible with dying and dead piglets. Despite the physical response to gag and run, the knowledge that these animals cannot even turn around and needed assistance was motivation to continue. Light from the video cameras highlighted sows lying in afterbirth, faeces, dead piglets, tethers caught in the skin of the sows' necks, bleeding welts, callused lesions, and chains too short, preventing the mother pigs from licking away afterbirth and chewing through umbilical cords. The light also gave testimony to mother pigs unable to reach their babies, tied by a steel chain—unnaturally fat, manacled food machines with no dignity, no consideration at all for natural inclinations, for basic comfort and for the fact that they too are sentient creatures. Part of the major stress suffered by intensively farmed pigs is that they are deprived of separate defecating areas, in direct contrast to their instinct for cleanliness.

The sows were all tethered, with the exception of a few. Their huge bodies lay half on concrete, the other half on wooden slats facing their food and water area. It was difficult to believe that the small concreted inserts were for water because there was no water in them at 3 a.m. The room for food was where thousands of maggots had taken up residence with the cockroaches. The remnants of the slop they are fed to put weight on as quickly as possible was hardly discernible as food. The activists reported watching as sows got their trotters caught in chains, the effort of getting up causing them to foam. They saw sows showing clinical stress symptoms, swaying back and forth and gnawing on the bars, intelligent brains deprived of any stimulus whatsoever.

It is difficult to view these animals and not think of the outcry that would happen were this to happen to dogs and cats. It is difficult to understand why prosecution is mandatory for ill-treatment of companion animals yet very little consideration is given for animals used for the meat market. Why is such a quantum leap even necessary in finding compassion for animals whose intelligence is deemed by many to be as high as or higher than that of dogs? If many of us who do own dogs thought of our own pets being chained in such conditions, I am sure we would immediately see how inappropriate such conditions were.

The evidence of cruelty in the piggery was so damning that on the same day that this piggery inspection occurred the New South Wales government announced it would ban all tethering of pigs—a welcome announcement. New South Wales is now the only state in Australia where the practice of tethering is completely banned. The day-to-day pain suffered by these intelligent, sensitive and curious creatures that are kept and bred as unnaturally fat food machines continues. It is important to emphasise the ongoing suffering that occurs in many intensive piggeries around the country. The particular irony of this piggery was that, whilst the suffering continued, the radio played love songs through the speakers as if to compensate for the concrete slabs, the lack of straw or bedding and the chains locking the pigs to single stalls.

As the Keating piggery debate still rages, with its various allegations of a hatchet job and the questioning of the credentials of Mr Keating's former partner, the debate nonetheless continues to ignore the true victims of the piggery operation and the conditions in which a large majority of Australia's pigs live. It is worth emphasising that, whilst many people feel it is difficult to do anything about this issue and they are often not aware of the specific details of the conditions that many intensively farmed animals have to endure, it is something that many Australians do have strong concerns about, particularly when they are made aware of the suffering.

I remind the Senate of a program screening on A Current Affair. While it is not quite the same as 60 Minutes, nonetheless it is a reasonably high profile program. It did show conditions in another piggery, following a similar inspection and videotaping by some animal rights activists in New South Wales accompanied by A Current Affair journalist Mike Munro, showing similar scenes to those which I have just described a few years later. I understand that the response to the showing of that particular program was amongst the largest public responses that A Current Affair has ever received to any item shown. That is a strong indication that such unnecessary cruelty is something that does concern many people and when it is brought to their attention they do demonstrate that concern. I believe the demonstration of that concern shows how crucial it is that governments, and indeed the industry itself, do more to address the unnecessary cruelty involved in many intensive piggeries around Australia.

talk.start.para: —I would like to speak tonight on the work of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Economics, Finance and Public Administration, particularly the work that has been published in its most recent report entitled Money too far away , which is a report on regional banking services. Then I would like to comment on some of the work that I have done as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry in the work of the Finance Forum, now known as the Agricultural Finance Forum.

speech.para: The removal of face-to-face banking, the aspect of banking which this report most strongly concentrates on, has had particular impact in rural and regional areas. The report looks at this phenomenon, which is a financial move taking place right across the world with leading edge technology that is probably unlikely to be reversed. It also looks at some of the alternatives that both banks and governments can offer in the light of these movements and some of the aspects of banking that lie ahead of us as we move on into the next century. The ability to both store and exchange money has always been one of mankind's strongest needs, along with the desire for food, good health and shelter. Banking has always existed in some form or another. These days we see such improvements as ATMs, electronic banking and the instant movement of money worldwide.

Given the undeniable fact that banks have thought it necessary to rationalise or close their services—not only in regional areas, I hasten to add, but also in metropolitan areas—the question arises as to how customers of those banks can access a similar service. This has taken place in many ways, as the committee's work goes on to detail, and I will briefly mention some of those. Firstly, there has been the development of credit unions and the enhancement of the way in which they can work. Some of the movements brought about by the Wallis reforms have certainly boosted the choice of consumers in the way in which they can access credit unions.

On 11 March 1999, the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, Joe Hockey, introduced groundbreaking legislation which will give regulatory responsibility to building societies, credit unions and friendly societies so that customers are able to use those. It is interesting to note that some 342 building societies, credit unions and friendly societies, which represent 1,326 branches nationally, with $38 billion in assets and 12,426 employees, will be able to be used by customers in order to access the sorts of financial services that they need. This is a very welcome change and it is part of the government's fundamental goals of increasing competition and improving efficiency but, at the same time, giving customers the guarantee that the financial system still provides integrity, security and fairness. That is most welcome.

Also, there has been the move to set up what are now called rural transaction centres. This means that the government has committed some $70 million over five years to establish up to 500 rural transaction centres in small towns around Australia with populations of fewer than 3,000. These are exactly the population centres that have been left, in many cases, without a single branch of a bank in the town. The funds for the rural transaction centres will be drawn from the sale of a further 16 per cent of Telstra. I can only ask that all non-government parties in the Senate regard the extension of this service as part of their community obligation to constituents, and that they will go on and vote for that further 16 per cent sale of Telstra.

The rural transaction centres program delivers not only such services as banking but also post, Medicare Ezyclaim, phone and fax facilities to communities that are no longer able to attract some or all of those services. This is indeed a very welcome development. As well as that, in my own home state of Victoria, we have seen the concept of com munity banks arise. This means that communities who find themselves in the situation with no financial institution can, of their own volition, put community money to help fund a community bank which is then run by the local community. That provides ownership of the financial institution at a community level, and should go on to ensure the survival of that institution when it is owned and run by the community.

The first two community banks opened in the middle of last year in the Victorian towns of Rupanyup and Minyip. Since then, many others have set up in centres such as Upwey, which is an outer suburb of Melbourne; Lang Lang in Victoria; Henty, in New South Wales; Toora, in Gippsland; Avoca, in central Victoria; and Wentworth and Coleambally, which are both in southern New South Wales. The Bendigo Bank, which deserves part of the credit for this, expects 15 branches to be operating by the end of June, with a further six to 10 by the end of the year. All of those are very rational type alternatives to the sort of banking that has been offered in the past.

As parliamentary secretary, I chair the Agricultural Finance Forum, which came about through recommendations of the National Rural Finance Summit held in June 1996. The forum attempts to facilitate better dialogue between the rural and financial sectors, and it hopes to help improve communication between the two sectors. I now chair that forum and I am very pleased with both the representative membership that we have on it as well as our terms of reference, which give us a very broad base. Basically, the forum is to increase the understanding of rural finance providers of the unpredictable nature of the commodity markets climate, and other factors which influence the profitability of farming, and how to, in turn, increase the rural community's understanding of financial sector operations.

Let me give you an idea of the broad base of membership that we have on this forum. I will not name them as persons but they represent such organisations as the National Farmers Federation, the senior agribusiness advisers of the Bank of Melbourne, Westpac, the National Australia Bank, the ANZ Bank and the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. Also represented are rural research agencies, rural adjustment and finance corporations, pastoral houses, chartered accountants, the Bankers Association, as well as representatives from the department. We also have rural councillors on that forum and a representative from the Credit Union Services Corporation. I would like to commend in my talk tonight those particular representatives who give very freely of their time and services in order to help rural communities. As chairman, I appreciate it very much.

Some of the things that the forum has looked at so far include the work of property management planning, which goes on in the different states, and how banks can better provide both product and information to serve the farming sector. We obviously took a great interest in the House of Representatives inquiry, which I have mentioned, increased competition in the agricultural sector and, as far as providing banking services goes, what the level of communication should be between the financial sector, the agricultural sector and government. In future, we hope to look at several other directions, particularly the culture of the banking practice and perceptions of the rural sector by media and urban areas.

I am very comfortable chairing that forum. As I said, I would like to commend the members of the forum who work in that area. I would also like to commend the work of the House of Representatives regional banking inquiry. The chairman was Mr David Hawker MP. This particular inquiry will lay the groundwork for many of the directions in which regional and rural banking and finance services go in the future. I commend the report to the Senate. It makes very interesting reading.

talk.start.para: —Tonight I wish to comment on the government's proposed legislation to give students freedom of choice. The government's legislation is designed to abolish the horrid and unacceptable compulsion and duress which has force-funded student unions and ensured their failure to be accountable to the student body at large. In recent times, people have sought to dress up compulsory student unionism in such terms as `universal membership'. They have tried to dress up the indefensible with a facade of respectability.

speech.para: My response to that very simply is—to use and abuse an old saying—that a rose by any other name smells just as sweet and that compulsory student unionism by any other name still stinks. No matter how people try to dress up the force, duress and compulsion which basically deliver to student unions around this country $100 million per annum, they are unacceptable in this day and age. In recent times, a very strange group have got together to support this completely unacceptable blot on tertiary life. One of them is the Law Institute of Victoria.

In my former manifestation as the chairman of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, might I say that I was continually impressed by representations by law bodies right around the country stressing the importance of legislation respecting the freedom of the individual. And here they are, urging compulsory student unionism on the one ground that compulsory student union fees employ a few solicitors around the country! Of course, that in itself is no justification for compelling students to join a student union. Indeed, if the legal services are so great and so good, I would have thought that the students would be joining voluntarily and saying, `We want to contribute to this because we know that we will be the beneficiaries.' So I must say that the law profession in Victoria has done itself a great disservice with its intervention in this debate.

What is most telling of course is the article of Friday, 12 March 1999 on page 4 of the Sydney Morning Herald, which reported, `First shots fired in war over uni fees'. We are told in a dramatic opening that about 1,000 university students protested nationwide against the federal government's plan to ban mandatory campus association fees—about 1,000 university students from a total student population in this country of 600,000. As a percentage, that represents 0.167 per cent of the student population. It just goes to show how representative these organisations are and how they have been living off the earnings of other students who are compelled and duressed into paying compulsory student union fees. Those that are seeking the ongoing maintenance of this abhorrent scheme are basically pleading in a self-serving, self-interested and selfish manner. I must say that their representations have been completely unimpressive.

For example, the University of Sydney Union's director, Dan Taylor, wrote to honourable senators in recent times and said, `The union is not a political body.' My response to that is,`So what?' I do not care what sort of a body it is. If it is a precondition to a student being entitled to a tertiary education, then it should be removed. Whether the union does good works or bad is, quite frankly, irrelevant to the debate. But suffice to say that so many bad works have been done that the push by many students for voluntary student unionism has increased. Why has it increased? Because as soon as membership is voluntary these student unions will have to deliver services, will have to deliver in a representative way so that they attract the students on a voluntary basis. And that is what the student leadership of this country is so scared about. They will actually have to be servants of the students. They will have to provide services and representation with which the students identify and for which the students will then agree to part with their money.

I am also told in this letter from the University of Sydney Union—and I must say that I hope this letter is not a representation of the intellectual rigour of that institution; I trust it is not—that only a member organisation can provide essential services on campus. Well, what an absolute nonsense. Essential services, if they are so essential, would have the students flocking to fund them. Surely students are big enough, old enough, mature enough, to determine what they consider to be essential. They will determine what they will fund, what they will not fund and what they determine to be essential.

In Western Australia we have now had voluntary student unionism for four years, and essential services are still on campus and students are still joining. But what was found in Western Australia is that student union fees have come down, the services have increased, and the student representation is a lot more democratic and a lot more representative of the student body, because the leadership know that if they embark on frolics of their own they will lose membership, they will lose funding and, as a result, they will go out of business. I say that, if so-called essential services on campus are essential, the students will make that determination individually by funding the student union.

Indeed, it seems to me not to make much sense to have a system whereby at the beginning of the year a student is required to make a compulsory contribution so that they can then, throughout the rest of the year, drink subsidised cups of coffee. Who are we conning in this? If it is so essential, why not just charge the service fee, so that those who want to drink a cup of coffee in fact pay the fee over the whole year rather than paying a huge subsidy at the beginning of the year so that they can enjoy that subsidy throughout the year? It really does not make much sense at all to make that assertion, as the union does.

Then we are told that the union is a large employer and an efficient organisation. Whether a union is a large or small employer is completely and utterly irrelevant in this debate, because the issue is student choice and student rights. And should it be that a university is entitled to tell a student, `If you don't join the student union, we will deny you a right to a tertiary education'? That is the issue we are dealing with. So whether the union is a large or small employer is totally irrelevant to the debate.

What about the assertion that it is an efficient organisation? If it is an efficient organisation, why are they scared to put themselves to the test and determine on the free market whether the students themselves believe that they are an efficient organisation? If the student body says, `Yes, you are an efficient organisation,' they will join the student union and there is no need for compulsion. In their heart of hearts they know that they are not efficient, that students would say, `We do not get value for money out of this,' and therefore would not join.

The most pompous of all arguments and the most distasteful is that `the union is integral to the cultural vibrancy of Sydney University'. What self-serving snobbery. How patronising to the student body. Can students not decide for themselves what sort of cultural vibrancy they want to engage in? We in fact do allow students to make a choice as to what course they embark upon. Why can we not let them decide what sort of cultural vibrancy—to use the term of the Sydney union letter—they want to be involved in? The blot of compulsory student unionism should be removed. It is not about student unions; it is about individual students having a choice. And we as a government stand very proud next to those students who want to exercise that choice.

subdebateinfo.title: Regional Forest Agreements: Logging in Victorian Forest Management Areas
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 405)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 12 February 1999:

question.para: With reference to evidence given to the Senate inquiry into the Regional Forest Agreements Bill 1998 that, in several forest management areas in Victoria, logging is occurring at levels well above those consistent with legislated maximum sustainable yields:
(1) What is the legislated maximum sustainable yield for sawlogs in the East Gippsland, Benalla/Mansfield, Midlands and Wodonga Forest Management Areas (FMAs) in Victoria.
(2) What quantity of sawlogs has been removed from each of these areas since licences were introduced in 1989.
(3) If sawlog removals exceed the legislated maximum, is this a breach of existing Regional Forest Agreements or those under negotiation.
(4) What action will be taken to ensure that overlogging does not occur.

(5) What action will be taken to stop the illegal reclassification of sawlogs as residual logs, which is clearly occurring in Victoria, and which is contributing substantially to overlogging in the above FMAs and others.
(6) If the Commonwealth took action to prevent either overlogging or reclassification of sawlogs to residual logs in RFA regions, would it be obliged to pay compensation to affected loggers.

talk.start.para: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

para.inline: Sustainable Yield Rates for Forest Management Areas1

answer.para: 1. Source: Schedule3, Victorian Forests Act 1958
(2) The Commonwealth does not hold this level of detailed information.

(3) The legal control of particular levels of timber harvesting is governed solely by Victorian State law, in particular by the Victorian Forests Act 1958. The issue of legality is therefore a matter for the State.

The Victorian legislation underpinning the observance of sustained yield was central to the Commonwealth's accreditation of Victoria's systems and processes as providing for ecologically sustainable forest management (ESFM). The existence of satisfactory State ESFM systems and processes, or commitments to improve to an acceptable standard, is a major component of Regional Forest Agreements.

Victorian Regional Forest Agreements include a number of specific commitments that taken together, ensure the long-term ecologically sustainable management of Victoria's forests. These include, for example, those provided in Clauses 40, 46, 47, 67 and 71 of the Central Highlands Regional Forest Agreement (RFA).

In addition, the RFA creates legally enforceable rights and obligations on the Commonwealth and Victoria in Part 3 of the RFA in relation to forest management, compensation, industry development funding and termination. Clause 92 permits the Commonwealth to terminate the RFA if the State fails to comply with certain provisions of the RFA after the observance of the dispute resolution procedures. These provisions include a failure by the State to implement the Integrated Forest Planning System and the Statewide Forest Resource Inventory in the region.

(4) The legal control of particular levels of timber harvesting is governed solely by Victorian State law. Under the RFA, the Commonwealth and Victoria agree that Victorian systems and processes, including its legislation, policies, Codes, plans and management practices, provide for the sustainable management of forests. In addition, RFAs are subject to five yearly reviews which include opportunities for public comment on the performance of the RFA.
(5) Classification of sawlogs in Victoria is the responsibility of the Victorian government.

(6) In the Central Highlands RFA, clause 90 of the Agreement sets out the terms and conditions pertaining to the payment of compensation for any action taken by the Commonwealth during the period of the Agreement. Under these terms and conditions, the State is to make a claim for compensation by a notice in writing to the Commonwealth which indicates the amount claimed, for whom the claim is made, the area to which it relates and which provides other detailed particulars.

subdebateinfo.title: Anderson, Dr Dennis: Chalkbrood Disease Tests
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 413)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, upon notice, on 18 February 1999:

question.para: (1) Has Dr Dennis Anderson, an officer of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, conducted DNA tests on chalkbrood disease.
(2) (a) When did those tests commence; and (b) what has been the purpose of his work in this area.
(3) Has Dr Anderson collected a large number of strains of chalkbrood disease from different regions of the world.
(4) Would Dr Anderson's work enable him to identify the source of the chalkbrood disease discovered in Australia in 1990.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Dr Denis Anderson, as an officer of the CSIRO, did conduct DNA studies on the causative agent of chalkbrood disease, which is a fungus that kills honey bee larvae.
(2) (a) Those studies commenced June 1993, after Dr Anderson confirmed the presence of chalkbrood disease in Australia in January 1993.
(b) The purpose of Dr Anderson's studies was to find a more efficient means of identifying the fungus responsible for causing the disease.

(3) As part of the work, Dr Anderson obtained a large number of chalkbrood isolates from bee colonies and fungal collections around the world. These were imported under strict quarantine and studied in an AQIS approved quarantine safe laboratory at CSIRO Entomology in Canberra.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 8 March 1999:

question.para: (1) With reference to the article in the Financial Review of Tuesday, 3 November 1998, under the headline `Multilateral Investment Pact on Ice', in which the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) is quoted as stating the Government's hope for reviving the Multilateral Agreement on Investment (MAI) eventually, saying that Australian Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) negotiators in Paris have sought to require that the agreement should be pared back to its core elements: what are the `core elements' the Government seeks to retain.

(2) With reference to a press release of the OECD's `International Investment Rules' dated 3 November 1998, in which it was confirmed that negotiations on the MAI were no longer taking place, but that OECD officials agreed on the importance of multi-disciplinary work on the desirability of establishing international rules for investment: what criteria would the Government seek to attach to Senator Kemp's stated intention to `carefully consider' the Government's approach to any further agreement on international investment rules.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The core elements are National Treatment; Most Favoured Nation Treatment; Investment Protection; and Dispute Settlement.

(2) The Government has indicated for some time that it had a number of serious concerns with the draft text of the MAI as it stood. The Government will not sign any agreement on international investment rules unless it is demonstrably in Australia's interest to do so. In that regard, any future negotiation would be subject to the continued scrutiny of established treaty making processes.
